title: When will the 7-day moving average of daily cases of COVID-19 in the US reported to the CDC next reach or exceed 200,000?
preds:
done.
Data Table for Daily Case Trends - The United States
Dec 26, 2021	164.644 ("New Cases")	206.577 ("7-Day Moving Avg")
It’s close.  If it doesn’t resolve before 31 Dec have time to change forecast.
BNO News reports a new average of 206.9k. CDC will likely report similar numbers. If 200k isn't reached today (Sunday), it'll be reached tomorrow.
Late on updating my percentages to 100%, but unfortunately was worried this might happen! Bummer shadow over the holiday/new year for sure. Stay safe out there, everyone.

@belikewater : your Xmas day dip came true.  Good forecasting sir! https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-09-08..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=New+per+day&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=GBR~USA https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-09-08..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=GBR~USA

adjusting up to 100% for bin 2 based on based on @Anneinak 's post:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1372867

I'd like to wish everyone here at GJO who celebrates it a Merry Christmas! And to those who don't, I wish you all Happy Holidays! I joined GJO this year, and I've really enjoyed forecasting with all of you this year. I appreciate our exchanges, and I thank you for sharing your insights. I'm glad to have "met" you all in this community.
@Anneinak @BayesianChimp @borisn @CJH @ctsats @DNK89 @Eliac @GMR @JonathanMann @kevins @m_collier @Maarten @Mark_T @MrLittleTexas @paulm @Ravi-Ivaturi1574726980 @Ryan-Beck @Scappleby @SE_Meyer @The_Fully_Clothed_Analyst
what's sort of astonishing about this is that these case counts don't include the obsessive self-testing also taking place (shortages aside).

Thanks @belikewater for keeping a comprehensive track of the 7 day avg projection over the holiday period and for aiming off for data tracking anomalies over the holiday. Now placing this as a certainty.  Note the sudden spike in 7 day avg fatalities as well and remember the human cost behind statistical forecasts.

It appears that the count for Dec 23rd is about 270k.
If that's correct, then for the 24th,25th, 26th & 27th the total count needs to be 680,999  which averages out to 170,250 per day. Counts won't be posted on the CDC website until Dec 27th,  but thanks to @belikewater  we have the NY Times: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/us/covid-cases.html
And, for the earliest case counts at the end of each day, we have BNO News (which tracks almost perfectly with the CDC): https://twitter.com/BNODesk

I think @belikewater is right, but the reason I'm not at 100% is that I'm not sure if there are / will be any unexpected reporting artifacts.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1372407

For Dec 23, BNO reports "more than 250,000 new coronavirus cases, with several states yet to report."
CDC reported cases:
Dec 18: 75,832
Dec 19: 93,431
Dec 20: 288,381
Dec 21: 204,913
Dec 22: 243,817
Preliminary data not from CDC for Dec 23: >250,000
Total: >1,156,374 So if tomorrow's number is ~243k, a 7-day average of 200k will be reached. If tomorrow's number is a little less, then 200k will be reached on Christmas. On Dec 25, the 76k on Dec 18 will fall off the 7-day average, and I can't imagine that Dec 25's number will be <159k, its value last year. If Dec 24 + Dec 25 >= 319k, or ~160k/day, then the 7-day average will be >200k on Dec 25. It is hard to see how Dec 24 and 25 won't average at least 160k. Moreover, this calculation is based on 250k cases for Dec 23, when several states have yet to report. If by some chance Dec 24 and 25 cases do not total to 319k, the Dec 19 number will fall off the 7-day average calculation for Dec 26. It's hard to imagine that the total cases on Dec 24, 25 and 26 could be <412k, or 137k/day. The dip last year, starting from a lower point, wasn't that steep. In addition, at least NYC has added testing capacity: https://twitter.com/bradlander/status/1472960115074637835 I think this is a done deal.
@Anneinak Later edit: BNO reports 270,271 cases for Dec 23!
https://twitter.com/BNODesk/status/1474222508110925827
So if tomorrow's number is ~223k, then 200k will be reached. Later later edit: NYT reports 265k cases for Dec 23.

Waiting for today's numbers from BNO News to confirm this forecast.... Should be available in about 3 hours.
https://twitter.com/BNODesk
So far for today:
NY: 38,835
FL: 32,869
IL: 18,942
OH: 15,989
NJ: 15,482
TX: 10,610
LA County: 8,633
Total of those: 141,360

with 243,817 cases reported for Dec 22nd, if each of the next 4 days are over 171k, the 7-day average will be over 200k HOWEVER:  I note this alert on the website: COVID Data Tracker will not update on Friday, December 24, 2021, Saturday, December 25, 2021, and Sunday, December 26, 2021. Updates will resume on Monday, December 27, 2021.
@belikewater

you start from the 20th… 20–> 288k, 21–> 204k, 22—>243k.
665left—>need to average 166k on other 4 days. 
Worldometer now at 97k for 23th, with just a few states counted and almost every state has a lot more than yesterday.
. If 23th is 250k cases ,you only need to average. 138k on the other 3 days. Seems done deal , imo (@belikewater sorry, hope I didn’t cost you too many for commenting on your early december forecast when you put high % in bin 2 when I was scared to. Never listen to me again 🤣.)
Reversing previous estimate to pre-January, 70/30 split, given recent jump in cases.
How the holiday interferes with testing seems like the deciding factor here. It looks to me like the average tips over 200k right on New Years day.

Now seems a projected inevitability, but I'd echo @m_collier 's sentiments remembering the human lives and life costs involved in these depressing forecasts. Lets just hope that the report about Omicron being less severe rings true across the board.

Another data point way over 200k for the 22nd. Case counts just have to be “flat” from here on out (statistically) to resolve things this week. I’m now pretty sure this will be the week, because Mondays are often anomalously large, but Wednesdays are often typical and not even the second-largest case count in any given week, when there is a growing wave. Would be very happy to be wrong though—obviously, such high case counts represent a lot of additional people who will soon be suffering or even dying.

CDC reported cases:
Dec 18: 75,832
Dec 19: 93,431
Dec 20: 288,381
Dec 21: 204,913
Preliminary data not from CDC for Dec 22: 242,794
Current 7 day average using Dec 22 data, from NYT: 171,380
Sum of Dec 18 to 22: 905,351
To reach 200k by Dec 24: need ~495k more => 247k average for Dec 23 and 24. This is possible.
Sum of Dec 19 to 22: 829,519
To reach 200k by Dec 25: need ~570k more => 190k average for Dec 23 to 25.
Suppose Dec 25 cases are ~175k. Then will need 198k/day on Dec 23 and 24. This is possible. Last December, cases fell by approx 1/3 from the upward trend they were on, over Dec 24 to 26 and the surrounding days. Dec 25 was on a Friday, and 159k cases were reported that day; 202k were reported the day before. The weekday pattern of reporting was not strong that month, though, the way it is now. We can expect a relative dip in reporting over Christmas and probably a few days before and after. I expect Dec 24 to be a bit below trend, Dec 25 to be substantially lower, and Dec 26 will be lower as it is a Sunday. I think it's moderately likely 200k will be reached by Dec 26. But it's quite possible that 200k will be reached next week as well, especially as the starting point is higher. Last weekend's case numbers were 76k and 93k. If this weekend's case numbers are 1.5x to 2x that, then 200k/day is likely in bin 2.

https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailycases 204k new cases today!  and 288k yesterday.
The 7-day average is now 161k.  The "gap" between the current 7-day average and 200k has decreased by half in 2 days.
The trend is upward. I think the peak is weeks out.

Considering how massively Omicron already swept through (the less densely populated) Canada, there's probably a freak tide in the U.S. with regards to new confirmed cases and test positivity rates (test positivity in Canada already surpassed 10%). I have no doubt reports for 22, 23, 24 Dec '21 will come out between 200k and 350k new cases each and will come out stronger than expected once a possible current backlog in "historic cases" reporting that I read in the CDC's data table time series starts getting cleared. 25 Dec and 26 Dec '21 with low expected TSA travel volume will be crucial for the question's possible resolution on bin 2, since these two points in the data will be included in any possible combination until 31 December '21.
If the 5 day-sum of cases between 20 and 24 Dec '21 comes close enough to 1,200,000 in total, there's robust chance that the remaining figures 25 and 26 Dec '21 will suffice to resolve the question despite low testing intensity and detection rate of infections over the holidays. [26 Dec '21 
25 Dec '21 
24 Dec '21 
23 Dec '21 270,271
22 Dec '21 243,619 245,638 736,913 663,088 165,772
21 Dec '21 204,913 246,647 493,294 906,707 181,341.5
20 Dec '21 288,381 ] [26 Dec '21

Last two days cases have been over 200K. Possible slowdown in testing over the holidays.
It’s going to be either December or January, and I’m leaning slightly January.
South African data shows a quick drop in daily cases following a quick spike, making February or later a likely non-starter as we are about one month behind them.

New cases Dec 22: 243,619; 7-day average: 167,477. The 7-day average rose 6.5%.
I do think 200k/day is likely, although possibly not before Dec 25 now. I think it probably won't quite make it to 200k before Christmas. I suspect it will be just under 200k on Dec 24, although 200k could still happen.

For Dec 22, New York state is reporting 28,924 cases, the largest number ever; their 7-day average is going to go up by 11%. Illinois reported 16,681 cases, and their 7-day average is going to go up 9%. If the rest of the US tracks similarly (a big "if"), the new 7-day average for Dec 21 could be ~10% up, or ~173k. If that happens, it's not too much of a stretch to picture >=200k/day on Friday. That would avoid the big holiday dip associated with Christmas as well. Later update: new cases Dec 22: 243,619; 7-day average: 167,477. The 7-day average rose 6.5%. Will adjust my forecast slightly down.

Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, day after Christmas have lower reporting rates – but this does not seem to hold on NYE and NYD.  I estimate, in the minimum, 270k cases reported on Thursday, Dec 23. Even with an average 20% underreporting rate (taken from last year) on Dec 24, 25, 26, and a recovery to Dec 23 on Dec 27, it is likely that the average cases reported will exceed 200k by Dec 31. However, there is a possibility of proportionally lower case reporting/testing relative to last year, and this needs to be accounted for. The situation w Omicron is odd and difficult to gauge – we have seen tests sell out in NYC, but in other areas, many think it is a cold. This is a question of willingness to take tests, hence I must allow for the possibility that the moving average does not exceed 200k by Dec 31.

Worldometer 197k today, and still 13 states without data… seems like 22th will again be >200k. Also x-mas still had arround 200k cases last year(24th of 2020 202k cases, 159k 25th). There was a drop during hollidays, but the drop was from a higher level. So it’s possible that when you’re not at that capacity level yet, but still at lower testing rate,  the drop will not happen?

If you start from the 20th… 20–> 288k, 21–> 204k. 908k left—>need to average 181k on other 5 days. That is not impossible if 2 more days would be arround 200k again. X-mas eve and day could have “off” days with smaller numbers.
I need to see one more data point before pushing bin 2 up further. But there is little doubt we will see the average over 200k over the next few weeks.

I see a lot of people forecasting fairly high probabilities for bin 2 over the past few days, and I wonder to what extent different people are taking into account lower testing/reporting rates that can be expected to occur over the holidays relative to what cases would be otherwise. There's a lot of uncertainty here, imo.
Mostly off the back of Yankee Candle complaint data (1), and ~288k cases on 20 December 1. https://twitter.com/zornsllama/status/1473575508784955394

Testing capacity over Christmas and new year season is a technical factor that might see this fall (just) into bucket 3, but using the UK's trend graph as an indicator of how steady the growth curve might be (straight as a die and nearly identical with the US since 14 Dec 21) [1]  it seems as a projection that the US 7 day average increase sits at 8000 new cases a day over the next couple of weeks (for comparison the last time the US hit 200,000 the daily increase rate was about 6000 cases a day on the up spike). If this trend holds then the US should reach 200,000 cases a day (7 day average) on the 28th or 29th December 21.  It'll be close but with the conditions not seeming likely to adjust the trend anyway but up (no new initiatives and no obvious reasons for an early peak or an easing of numbers outside limitations on capacity to test and record) it looks like a fair punt to make that we'll hit the 200,000 mark just before the turn of the year (and the move into bucket 3). [1] https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-06-23..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=desc&pickerMetric=total_cases&Metric=Confirmed+cases&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=USA~GBR

Only a few days left until December 31st.  The testing might have trouble keeping up with the surge in Omicron cases. The holidays will further limit testing. The question is a 7 day average, and so will likely be decided soon, one way or the other.

Big jump in cases today in spite of decrease expected from “holiday reporting issue”. This will apparently be a race between Omicron on one hand and US testing/reporting limits on the other to determine if the 200k mark is exceeded just before or just after New Year’s.
Using London as a demographic pre cursor of speed of spread.
The only reason I am not higher is testing capacity for Christmas and the timing of being. If don't hit Bin2 then it will be the following week I suspect
A jump to 298 (or 270) is a big jump. Watching a few cities the numbers are looking UKish. I will follow daily numbers for a couple of days but I am thinking that we should be hitting bin2 hard soon

I was going to wait for the rest of the week to see what case counts do, but at this point, why not put some probability on an 80k/day increase in the 7-day avg. taking place in just ~ 2 weeks. Just because it’s absolutely bonkers doesn’t mean it’s not happening. With Omicron, the more unlikely it seems, the more likely it is to happen apparently.

The NYT has 270k cases on December 20th (299k minus the 29k Maryland data blip).  This is higher than my estimate a few days ago. The surge is accelerating.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/us/covid-cases.html

New cases Dec 20: 268,307 excluding MD backlog of 28,541 cases
7 day average: 142,973 (+10,163)
https://twitter.com/BNODesk/status/1473106730343145472
Reported cases are going up despite the holidays. That tells you just how much Omicron is spreading.
There might just be an upset, and this question might resolve in bin 2. But I do think reported cases will very likely drop after this Friday, so if cases are going to reach 200k, it would need to happen fast.

The 7-day moving average was more than 130k  on December 19th. New York City is seeing a dramatic increase in cases.  NYC population is 8 million, but the daily confirmed cases will be limited by test capacity. There are reports of long lines in NYC to get tested, with more test sites opening up this week. The CDC wants more data, and is surely watching NYC closely.  This question is going to be close between bin 2 and bin 3. Putting the cutoff on the holiday makes the question more dependent on some random decisions. Will states report on New Years Eve? Will Maryland get back online? Will the CDC work on New Years Eve? Many have had enough of 2021, and look forward to a new year. Happy New Year! "For the fourth consecutive day, New York state saw a record level of positive COVID cases with 23,391... De Blasio said the city currently has 89 brick-and-mortar testing sites up and running and plans to add 23 more by the end of this week."
https://abc7ny.com/nyc-covid-testing-tests-coronavirus-new-york/11360650/ "Using today's published numbers as a baseline, 24-hour changes will resume tomorrow, 12/21/21... MDH will pause COVID-19 reporting on Nov. 25 and 26; Dec. 24 and 25; and Dec. 31 and Jan. 1 in observance of the holidays. "  https://coronavirus.maryland.gov/
Still sitting on the fence on this one a little bit. That reported cases are going up at all right now is a testament to just how much actual cases are going up.

@belikewater has made some points that I consider important. . . 
-increased use of quick, at-home testing may decrease # of tests taken at test sites and reported to the CDC
-a tsunami of new cases may overwhelm test sites & labs, delaying counts
-last year there was a significant (approx 18%) slowing/decrease in the # of tests reported during the holiday period, perhaps due to:
     -short-staffing due to holidays & illness (omicron!) at testing sites & labs may further delay testing
     -employees of businesses which close for the holidays will not be being tested Offsetting these factors will be
-increased airline travel over the holidays (but this happened last year, too)
-any changes in airline requirements and/or state or international requirements
-increased infectiousness of the omicron variant The CDC is reporting 132,659     as of Dec 19th. . . .short of 200k by 67,341 with 10 days to go before the close of bin #2.  
There's not been such a big increase in cases in a 10-day period before (max increase in 10 day period looks to be about 50k)
however, omicron appears to be far more infectious than earlier variants. I'm older than NATO and my background is in the soft sciences;  I don't have the math & computer skills to plot curves.  So, I enlarged the graph, copy-pasted the last 10 days onto a piece of paper, printed it, then used a ruler & pencil to extend the current curve 10-20-30 days.  At the current rate of increase, it appears to me that there won't be a 7-day average of cases over 200k until towards the end of January even though on some days recently the case counts have been around 190k. For 200k to be achieved, omicron would have to be far more infectious and there must be an equal ramping up of testing & reporting.
Possible, but growing less likely as data seems to suggest that the steepest part of the omicron variant curve will be after Jan 1st. EDIT:  corrected mis-use of "virulence" in the 2nd to the last sentence.  (Thanks @belikewater for catching that!)

Rethinking. We really need to see what happens this week. The highest 7-day average of cases/day for all of December last year was on the Sunday before Christmas, so Dec 19 would likely be the peak this year, too, if it weren't for Omicron, and Dec 31 would be the minimum during the holidays. This week we will start to get an idea of whether Omicron's growth will overcome reduced testing during the holidays and increased use of home tests.

The number of people getting tests sure doesn't seem to be slowing down.
Just one example: https://twitter.com/MarkLevineNYC/status/1472576237788880907
And that's an awful lot for a Sunday: "New York reports 22,478 new coronavirus cases, the biggest one-day increase on record, of which 12,404 are in New York City" https://twitter.com/BNODesk/status/1472667941829283847
US Covid cases last Sunday: 35.5k. Today: 64.7k. NY state alone has 22.5k cases. Over 7.6k cases in Ohio.

Cases at 127.7k and trending upwards after a short dip (up from 119k last week). Omicron not being reflected in the numbers as quickly as I would have expected.  Possible that many people are now relying on the at-home tests which would not be officially reported.  Leaving my Bin 2 projection at 20%. No sign of Omicron abating, so I am more confident than previously that this will happen in bins 2 or 3.  Reducing my bin 4 prediction from 5% to 2% and my bin 5 prediction from 10% to 3% Increasing bin 4 projection from 65% to 75%
I think testing and reporting will likely fall too much during the remainder of the year to reach 200k/day by then. Otherwise, I think it would definitely happen before Dec 31.

Daily cases are starting to increase, from 118k to 125k in the last week. New York City and Florida are examples of how quickly cases can double. Maybe above 130k on Dec 19th, and above 200k on Dec 29th.

Some very troubling signs from a highly vaccinated populace. Models show daily new cases likely to surge past last winter’s highs.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/12/18/omicron-variant-denmark/
Cases jumped last week, so 200K this month is possible. Before March seems really likely given Omicron.

Today's number for the 7 day average is 122,296.  To have a 7-day average of 200k cases by 12/31, there will have to be an AVERAGE increase in the AVERAGE of 5,5xx per day.  Looking at the new cases per day (orange line), there's a significant increase in cases per day which is going to translate into a significant increase in the 7-day average.
Bin 2 seems possible if there is a rise in Omicron cases that is as rapid as in the UK/EU. If not Bin 2 then it's hard to see it going past Bin 3.

Based on last year, we could expect case reports to dip from today through early January from where they would have been without the holidays, with a minimum on Dec 31. However, I suspect that with Omicron exploding, I expect cases to continue to increase at least somewhat through late next week, and I think we may still see a 7-day average of 200k before Dec 31. But it will likely be a nailbiter, and it might resolve to bin 2 only on Dec 31. With Omicron cases exploding, I also think that increasing use of at-home rapid tests will reduce reported cases.
Watch and wait.

As I expected would likely happen, the doubling time in at least one community where they are actually collecting a lot of data is ~2.2 days. I suspect that the previously estimated doubling time of 3.7 days resulted from insufficient data.
https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1471651856011051011 As I've said before, the only reason why I don't have a really high weight on bin 2 is that case reporting will almost certainly dip during the holidays compared to what it is normally. But I'm really starting to think that even with a dip in reporting, the US could well see a 7-day average of 200k/day. Cases and testing are heating up in the US:
https://twitter.com/DWUhlfelderLaw/status/1421850646697975813
https://twitter.com/JesseRodriguez/status/1471573837959544842
https://twitter.com/sharonNYT/status/1471578746813620226
https://twitter.com/thehill/status/1471458619963105287
https://twitter.com/MarkLevineNYC/status/1471619839466909699
https://twitter.com/NBCNews/status/1471624686446551047
https://twitter.com/LadyBug67072655/status/1471698616150634499
https://twitter.com/K_G_Andersen/status/1471364364284284929

The 7-day average is 118,515.  
This represents an increase of 37.3% over the past week.
If this rate of increase continues, in 2 weeks the 7-day average will be 222,441.  
However, the omicron variant seems to be more contagious than delta, so I'm expecting the increase WoW to exceed 37.3%.
BUT, there's the problem that last year there was a period at the holidays in which there was an 18% drop in reported cases; I'm assuming that this was due to short-staffing because of the holidays.
That reduces my confidence in an estimate that the 7-day average of cases will exceed 200k by CYE. If the data next week shows a higher rate of WoW increase, I'll be increasing my forecast for prior to CYE.
This seems worth noting. There's still plenty of uncertainty. https://twitter.com/ScottGottliebMD/status/1471670787853725706?t=YguWuedpoaw4sC2Yyz3v6w&s=19

Cases are rising very fast, so 200K is possible this year, but not likely. But early next year is looking quite likely. Cases have been rising very rapidly. A lot of vulnerable people, and a lot of resistance to masking in many places. Better uptake on vaccines, but they don’t offer instant immunity.

US daily cases remain flat around 120k. New York City is starting to see exponential growth in daily confirmed cases [1]. Less than 20% in the US have taken a booster dose, and a booster is needed to prevent Omicron infection, and so Omicron will spread rapidly, but it will take a few weeks. The previous increase from 120k to 200k took about 4 weeks (November 9 to December 7, 2020). Omicron will spread faster, maybe in 1 to 3 weeks. But it hasn't started yet, except in NYC. 1. "Um, we've never seen this before in #NYC," Varma tweeted, noting that the daily positivity rate on Dec. 9 was 3.9% and appeared to have doubled by Dec. 12 to 7.8%.  "This is #SARSCoV2 evading both vaccine & virus induced immunity *against infection* unlike any variant before. That's only explanation for dramatic jump in positivity. Consensus for now (but subject to change) is that immunity *against severe disease* should be far better," he went on to tweet."
https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/coronavirus/weve-never-seen-this-before-in-nyc-covid-positivity-rate-doubles-in-3-days-as-omicron-spreads/3454450/

US cases have plateaued, but it feels like the calm before the storm. Based on data from London showing the Omicron wave as substantially worse than previous Delta wave I am comfortable reducing my 33% "not at all" prediction from 33% to 10%.  Similarly reducing March/April prediction from 10% to 5% Still do not think that it is likely that we breach the 200k threshold in December, but it is more likely than it was previously.  Revising up from 8% to 20% 65% that we hit the 200k number in January or February

1) as pointed out by @borisn , the “effective” doubling rate of Omicron is likely to be slower than the 2-3 day “single-reservoir” doubling rate that is often cited in reference calculations, and that seems to be based primarily on case-rate evolution in South Africa and UK. The main argument I’ve seen for why this would be is related to the spatial and social compartmentalization of the US, and the need for the virus to “jump” into new sub-populations before it can continue to spread. This process would cause some delay in the onset/growth rate of the wave that would make a bin #2 outcome pretty difficult to achieve (only 2 weeks left), given today’s case counts. 2) as pointed out by @belikewater, the US was seen to have a pronounced dip in cases last holiday season that was a pure artifact of detection/reporting delays. There is a high chance that we will see a repeat of this effect again this year. Apparent case counts will therefore be lower (possibly by much more than 10%), thereby further reducing chances of a bin #2 outcome. Avoiding bin #2 gives no comfort at all since it’s hard to see any other outcome than a massive Omicron spike sweeping the country early in 2022 / bin #3 causing all kinds of additional sickness, death, and economic problems. It seems shocking how little coverage there is even now about the danger, and how little is being done to try to “flatten the curve”. Is Dr. Fauci out of gas?

New York City is the only large US population I can find that might be seeing exponential growth in daily confirmed cases. US daily cases remain flat around 120k. The highest Nowcast estimate is 13% Omicron share in Region 2. Daily confirmed cases in this region are:
New York (excluding NYC): 7k flat
New York City: 4k increasing with a 10-day doubling time.
New Jersey: 4.5k increasing with a 13-day doubling time. Omicron doubling time has been estimated at 4 days, but this might mostly apply to cities. The US overall might see something closer to the 8-day doubling time Delta had in July 2021. I expect 130k to 200k to take about 8 days with a 4-day doubling time, and about 17 days with an 8-day doubling time (with constant Delta cases). My estimates:
130k daily cases (7 day avg): Dec 20 to 30
130k to 200k: 8 to 17 days
200k daily cases (7 day avg): Dec 28 to Jan 16
probability before Jan 1: 4/20 = 20%

Today the average is 117,890.  So the average would have to increase by 82,111 for this question to close. Looking at the graph, the shortest period of time during which the average increased by 82k was about 17 days:  Nov 8-25.
That would put us at 200k by Dec 30. . . barely  . . .  However, I think that because of Thanksgiving & Christmas socializing and the emergence of the more highly contagious Omicron variant, which seems to be infecting double-vaccinated people at the same rate as un-vaccinated, I think we'll see an even steeper curve and get to 200k sooner than Dec 30th. However, @belikewater makes a good point about the dip of 18% in reported cases possibly due to under-reporting after Christmas last year. If the omicron variant causes as rapid of an increase in cases as I am anticipating, all systems may become overwhelmed.  With short-staffing over the holidays to add to this, the count could again be under-reported by 18% or more. Absent the issues of holiday under-reporting and systems overwhelmed by an unprecedented increase in cases, I'd have forecast 33% for prior to Dec 30.  However, I will reduce that by 1/2%. . . that puts my forecast a bit higher than the mean of the most recent forecasts by the forecasters I am following . . . I'm ok with that.
I think we would see 200k/day if it weren't for the dip in reporting over the holidays.
My guess: 130k to 200k takes 1 week. Above 130k on December 19th. Above 200k on December 26th.  I will update my probabilities when I see more than 130k daily cases (7 day moving average).

If it weren't for the holidays, I'd be 100% on bin 2; I'd expect cases to rise to 300k+/day by the end of the year. If testing/reporting will be effectively capped during the holidays enough to keep the 7-day average below 200k/day, then it'll be bin 3. If testing/reporting are only cut by a *percentage*, say around 20% like last year (18% last year), then it'll be bin 2. I'm not sure which way this is going to go.

Currently at 119k and trending upwards (up from 108k last week).  Although there seems to be a lull in upward trajectory in the last few days. Omicron still not prevalent Hit 200k on December 9th last year Today's number of cases were hit November 10th last year, so took slightly less than 1 month to from where we are now to 200k. I have no idea what will happen next. 
Prior expectations—supported by the observable evidence reported in all the official channels (CDC)—indicate that Delta on its own will be unlikely to cause another very large wave anytime soon. Omicron, however doesn’t seem to have nearly the volume of officially reported case data that I’d expect to see based on comments in this GJO forum and twitter, but there’s a lot of reasonable arguments for why we should expect a spike soon. It is quite disturbing to me that nobody seems to be able to actually demonstrate with population-scale (more than a few dozen anecdotes) case data that Omicron is evolving comparably to the UK in any specific US location yet. I can buy that we have generally poor surveillance on average in this country, but it’s hard to swallow that there is as of yet—weeks after the variant was apparently introduced—no city, state or district where we can actually prove Omicron’s spread, at catastrophic speeds and efficiency, and yet many knowledgeable folks here are apparently near-certain that a huge wave will erupt on us any minute now—or in a couple of weeks at latest. Delta WAS reported for several weeks by CDC at smaller percentages before it really exploded as I recall.  Is there really no chance that the emperor’s wearing no clothes? To be more precise: is there really no chance that Omicron will have a flatter-than-expected curve and/or later peak case rate, such that we could still reach bin# 5? I am not in any way suggesting there won’t be a big wave!
Adjusting December down due to passage of time, and a growth rate that is insufficient to reach 200,00. Adjusting the next bib up for Omicron.

Given how quickly Omicron is spreading in the UK, I suspect the US is not far behind. The US could possibly see 200k cases/day from Delta + Omicron by the end of the year. We simply don't have the surveillance that the UK does, so we're flying relatively blind in comparison.
In favor of 200k by the end of the year (bin 2):
* Omicron is spreading widely, and Delta + Omicron cases may actually reach >> 200k/day.
* Many locations have little to no restrictions in place.
* People aren't changing their behaviors much and still don't anticipate the speed of exponential spread.
In favor of bin 3 instead:
* Testing and reporting go way down during the holidays. Reported cases fell 25% over Thanksgiving, despite actual cases rising. Last year, reported cases fell 18% over Christmas and New Year's, despite actual cases rising.
* Perhaps related to the point above, could testing capabilities become saturated in some locations?
* Locations could put substantial restrictions in place.
* Omicron may not be as widespread as I think it likely is.

It is starting to look more likely that in addition to escaping much existing immunity, Omicron may be more transmissible. There's still little evidence that can separate out increased transmissibility vs. increased immune escape, but I found this to be a rather compelling graph that supports the idea that Omicron may actually be more transmissible: https://twitter.com/rid1tweets/status/1466828284445040645
And here's one among several estimates of R0 by highly respected scientists: https://twitter.com/macroliter/status/1466808886342651909 But meanwhile, there's Delta. 157k cases today, 139k yesterday, 137k Wednesday, 109k Tuesday. Today's cases will put the 7-day average at ~113k/day. It's looking increasingly possible that we'll see >200k cases in one day soon, but it's still not clear whether we'll see a 7-day average of 200k/day. Thanksgiving messes up all the data. In a few more days, we'll get a better idea of what Rt looks like and where it might be heading. I have a feeling it'll be back over 1.1 in a few days and that we'll be pushing towards 200k. Looking at last year, I think we can expect that the highest number in December will be reached on Friday, Dec 17. After that, cases will dip around the Christmas holidays and not rebound until early January. So for 200k to be reached in bin 2, it would need to be reached by Dec 17. That's in 14 days - it's a really tight schedule. If cases reach nearly 200k/day by next Friday, then it's possible. This would mean cases would need to accelerate faster this year than last year, but that's a reasonable possibility because this year, Delta is circulating. Come January and February, we can expect Omicron to start dominating cases as Delta cases die down (likely not because of Omicron, but in parallel to it). I expect we'll see a big surge in Omicron cases starting in January, and it's not clear to me how much we're going to do to try to slow it down, because mitigations have become so politicized and 1/3 of the country opposes even wearing masks. So, if Delta doesn't push us to 200k in Dec or early Jan, then Omicron will in Jan or Feb. If we do mitigate the spread of Omicron in Jan and Feb, then I think we'll likely make it to May 1.

Prior to the new Omicron variant I would have said 1 Jan- 28 Feb would have been low probability (~<10%), but with that uncertainty I feel the need to increase that to closer 25%. Very hard to predict beyond 1 March at this stage but leaning towards better awareness (both govt. and general public) leading to more caution ensuring the number stays below 200k until after 1st May.
139k cases on Dec 3 and increasing. There's a real possibility of reaching a 7-day average of 200k/day by the end of the year.

Significantly increased the modeled transmissibility rate starting 20 days from now. 
Previously already modeled increased mobility during the Holiday Season.

Based on peak months for upper-respiratory infections (due to lower humidity and increase of in-person gatherings), COVID is likely to peak between December and February (with February being the most likely month, if only based on trends from other upper-respirator viruses). 200,000 cases were reached in December for COVID last year, but this was without an available vaccine and with social distancing measures implemented nation-wide. This will be the first winter season with most restrictions lifted, but with vaccines available. As summer cases were higher in 2021 than summer 2020 (after governments lifted restrictions), COVID is widely in circulation, and more infectious than the flu, I predict reaching 200,000 cases in December for the 7 day moving average is likely. COVID cases may instead peak in historically high months for the flu (February) due to vaccination/booster schedules.

It's not clear to me whether enough of the US has the political will at this point to put enough of a limit on the size of a potential Omicron wave, which would likely explode in late Jan to mid Feb in the absence of mitigation. If 100 cases were present in the US as of 11/27/21 and the doubling time is 5 days (one current estimate is 4.8d), then we could see ~100k cases/day by the end of January.
But I don't rule out Delta putting us over 200k cases/day by the end of the year.
I also don't think Omicron is the only variant that may spread well in the US. For example, it's possible that Omicron could turn out to escape nearly all neutralizing antibody immunity but be barely more transmissible than the ancestral variant, while some other variant (B.1.1.640? Others?) could turn out to escape some intermediate portion of existing antibody immunity but be more transmissible than Omicron. Which would spread more quickly in the US (and elsewhere), and how much would they spread? And what restrictions would be put in place to limit their spread (probably not much)?

A closer look at the 2020-2021 US holiday wave shows its  “compound” nature (three, progressively larger new caseload spikes separated by two significant dips). A commonly encountered interpretation of this observation is that there is 1) a lull in testing / strong incentive to delay seeking medical treatment until directly after the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays while families are gathered; 2) significantly increased chances for new infections driven by large numbers of people traveling together in confined spaces and gathering indoors for festivities with trusted family members. This explains the apparent dip in cases coinciding with the specific holiday dates and the strong rebound in cases beyond previous highs thereafter. If the above paradigm holds for 2021-2022 holidays, then we are currently at the pre-Thanksgiving maximum caseload and should see a drop in cases over the next few days/week (Thanksgiving) followed by a large rebound in mid-December, and another dip in the second half of December, with the ultimate maximum caseload from the current holiday peak expressing in early January. Comparison of current avg. caseloads vs those seen a year ago shows that we are nationally still far below levels seen then (just below 100k now vs ~170k then).
A year ago, the post-Thanksgiving “rebound spike” was the one that first rang the bell for > 200k cases, and it eventually exceeded the pre-Thanksgiving maximum by about 50k cases. If the same increase vs current levels were to occur this year, we’d still be quite safely below 200k. I am convinced that all evidence points to this year’s post-Thanksgiving “rebound spike” being smaller because of the impact of vaccination and because the massive uptick in cases is not happening everywhere in the US at the same time.  Therefore I’m now eliminating the possibility of a 200k+ spike in bin #2. Further analogy with 2020-2021 shows the post-Christmas “rebound spike” shooting up to exceed the previous maximum by a further 40k cases. If both expected 2021-2022 “rebound-spikes” (post-Thanksgiving AND post-Xmas) do end up expressing with a similar magnitude to the previous year’s outcome, then we really could plausibly see another (barely) 200k+ ultimate maximum, so adjusting probability for bin #3 accordingly. Bin #4 was also adjusted to account for the simple passage of time.
Must be in winter.Especially in the coldest time.

I'm starting to think that some of the immunity in the US has acquired so far by infection and/or vaccination may be overcome by Delta's transmissibility and by time (leading to waning immunity). I had thought that the Delta wave would likely wrap up in Dec, perhaps after a small, gentle rise in cases around now, but looking at Europe and at the steepness of the current rise of cases in the US, I'm beginning to think that might be wrong. Delta is still very much making its way through the US population, and almost no mitigations are in place. Also, there's B.1.640 to worry about. I also looked at this twitter thread: https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1448297975537623047
In this thread, Trevor Bedford (a respected virus geneticist) speculates that each year, ~20% to 30% of the US will be infected.
That right there is approaching last winter. And that's with typical antigenic drift; a year with a much greater antigenic change in the virus (as might be the case for B.1.640) could see more. Now, the situation he's discussing is not exactly the same as what we're facing now, as many locations have only recently experienced a Delta wave, etc. But it gives me pause, as I had been thinking that in a typical year, ~10% of the population would get infected.
With the recent sudden increase in Europe and USA, I have adjusted my forecast to reflect the possibility that we could see a 7 day average above 200k before the end of this year.

I'm wondering whether vaccinations might be outweighed by Delta's increased infectivity and waning immunity to the extent that we could see a fairly large spike this winter. Especially if Delta Plus or some other variant becomes a bigger problem.

Adjust for passage of time. As cases are starting to tick up in the Northern most states, and as we also see an uptick in Europe, I think it is increasingly likely that we will see a repeat of last year's numbers.

Given rates of vaccination, booster, reduced tests ans natural immunity I don’t think it is as likely to get a big peak again as far as 200k a week.  In addition different parts of the country are now in independent cycles and one part of the country will have a wave when another one eases off.  So the different rates in different states balances off.  All states would need a surge at the same time as happened before.
If people travel over Christmas there is a possibility in January of higher rates, but the travel is the cause.
So I think this level of infection is unlikely to happen again, but still giving it a reasonable probability before May anyway.

CDC reports cases detected.  Last time cases exploded, there was not a day over 200 000.  If severity rises again, it will increase hospital use, and decrease cases reported by CDC.  The only things that could change that would either be a massive rise in testing, a decrease in vaccine efficacy, or a decrease in severity.  A decrease in severity would increase actual case count, but would also reduce detection.  Unless the disease gets back into the population that actually gets tested, it's not going to happen.  (And cases are about to drop a bunch as people <12 get the vaccine.)  Waves take too long to happen in November, and require synchronization.
Unreported cases will rise significantly as a mix% because the severe cases will continue weakening substantially.
Either we will have turned the corner or we won't have.

Apparently I’m on the completely opposite end of the “thought-spectrum” on this Question, compared to @belikewater : I’m fighting an urge to put too much weight in bins 2-4! I am nevertheless making a very minor adjustment triggered by:
- a recent uptick in reporting on a new COVID delta sub-variant observed in Europe, e.g., [1]
- a new estimate that it may actually have somewhat higher transmissibility than initially reported [2]
- widely acknowledged remaining uncertainty So far, everything only points to an “early indication” that (hopefully and very likely) will prove to be insignificant. I am (for now) pulling ~3% probability back from bin #5 to reflect a new scenario where this delta sub-variant (AY.4.2) or its future mutants become much more of a factor in the US COVID story than is currently anticipated, leading to an unexpected new, large peak in cases.  Apparently AY.4.2 is responsible for a small but growing share of cases in the UK. “At this stage, experts don't think AY.4.2 is likely to take hold - so in time it could well burn out and drop off the watch list.” [1] “ Prof Francois Balloux, director of University College London's Genetics Institute, said: "It is potentially a marginally more infectious strain.
"It's nothing compared with what we saw with Alpha and Delta, which were something like 50 to 60 percent more transmissible. So we are talking about something quite subtle here and that is currently under investigation.
"It is likely to be up to 10 percent more transmissible.” [1] Today, reported that Israel’s Health Ministry thinks that we’re dealing with something that’s “15% more contagious than Delta.” [2] “The UN health agency is currently tracking 20 variations of the Delta variant. The AY.4.2 is “one to watch because we have to continuously keep an eye on how this virus is changing,” said Van Kerkhove [World Health Organization’s technical lead on COVID-19]. In the US, the Delta variant accounts for nearly all COVID-19 cases. The newer AY4.2 Delta variant has been spotted “on occasion,” but it’s not yet a concern, health officials said.” [2] For me, this story seems worth watching closely, as reporting on it seems to be rising “above background” and because throughout the COVID outbreak, major new developments generally first express in the news as seemingly minor local developments that gradually become reported as more serious factors. Fingers crossed AY.4.2 will not be one of these (go bin #5!). [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/health-58965650
[2] https://www.timesofisrael.com/health-ministry-says-new-delta-mutation-ay4-2-appears-to-be-15-more-infectious/

I've been thinking about this question and more broadly, about what the pandemic looks like next. It would take a new variant with substantial immune escape to cause a wave this big. It would need to be able to infect ~15% of the population. Right on the heels of Delta, no mild immune escape variant is going to be able to do that. And we've been seeing incremental immune escape evolution. And this virus mutates more slowly than flu viruses (per copy made). I just can't see a wave in which 15% are infected until perhaps next winter at the soonest. At least let's hope.

We are around 150K cases per day now, and the rate is falling. Covid cases rates are hard to predict, and they turn around quickly. Fall weather could trigger a turn around, as could cases spread in schools.

So the CDC just released the new forecasts and as mentioned below, volatility between forecasts is quite high.   Surprisingly, they have significantly reduced the variance of predictions:  from 42k to 31k cases per day.  This makes a world of difference in the projections particularly early on.  I have partially updated to reflect these changes.  This has drastically reduced the Monte Carlo simulation results posted below.

Wow a lot of people here seem very optimistic.   Considerations:
1) We really haven't had that many days in total above 200k
2) Partially & Fully Vaccinated: 212M People
3) People that have had it:  42M
4) Models for the # of cases are all over the map and these are only out a few weeks:  
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasts-cases.html
5) 40% of models as of the end of August would have had projected breaking 200k:
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasting-us-cases-previous.html
6) R0 is approximately 4.5-7.5 --== First Step:  Simply decide if it's plausible to see continued growth  ==-- --== Susceptible Individuals ==--
Looking at #2/#3 and adjusting for efficacy:
Susceptible Vaccinated People = Vaccinated * (1-Efficacy) = 212 * (1-0.78) = 46M
Susceptible Prior Infection = Cases * (1-Immunity) = 42 * .98 = ~1M
Unprotected Population = 78.1M 
% of Unprotected Population:  78.1 / 333 = 23.4%
Herd Immunity Ratio = 77%
Implied Herd immunity threshold = 85%   This suggests that we aren't quite at where we need to be for herd immunity to take root and force the virus out without additional vaccinations, mobility, or masking.  Based on the forecasts by the crowd thus far, it appears they believe we are already at this threshold.   --== Step 2:  Modeling & reliability ==--
Since we now have a basis for believing that it could continue to spread... time to turn to the models and evaluate the likelihood.
After evaluating the 23 models listed by the CDC that forecast the next few weeks (See link above).   We notice a trend (each week we gain reduce the average but increase the standard deviation accordingly):
1 Week Forecast (7-Day Avg):  140k, StDev = 25k
2 Week Forecast: 130k, StDev = 35k
3 Week Forecast: 120k, Stdev = 42k
4 Week Forecast: 110k, StDev = 55k  Rolling these through a daily auto-regressive (i.e. new mean is based on the 7 day average) Monte Carlo Model spits out the probabilities allocated.  Unfortunately this is very cumbersome to update even though we do get new results daily and new forecast models from the CDC weekly. Note: I did not adjust the distribution of the Monte Carlo Simulation at all for the purposes of my first projection.

Data Observations:
- In ~1.5 years, the US apparently experienced three "simple" new infection peaks (none of which exceeded even 100k/day) and two "compound" new infection peaks that are larger and have internal sub-peaks/troughs. At least one of the compound peaks exceeded 200k/day (Nov20-Jan21 peak; we are currently in the midst of the second "compound" peak, TBD if it will exceed 200k/day)
- By eyeball, during approximately half of the time interval since the first COVID outbreak, there was no active new infection peak (steady or falling baseline), and the longest between-peak time interval was roughly 4 months. The two "compound" peaks observed so far are 6-7 months apart.
- The current new infection rate during the ongoing "compound peak" (Sep21) is now at ~150k/day, although this value has been stagnant for a while now. The previous compound peak achieved ~150k/day, and rapidly progressed to exceed 200k/day, whereas the current compound peak seems significantly "flatter" at present.
- During the period of COVID, only the Delta variant emergence seems to significantly have changed the evolution of COVID in the US (beyond the initial COVID strain to hit the US population).  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html Assumptions/Interpretation:
- Heightened indoor visitation during vacations and holidays can drive new infection peaks. Timing of increased new infection impacts arising from this behavior are highly predictable.
- Emergence of new virus variants can be another major trigger of new infection peaks. Timing of significantly more infectious virus variants emerging is completely unpredictable. History suggests that new, worse variants don't emerge super frequently (not 5x/year, for example), although the recurrence timing and impact on the vaccinated is still extremely uncertain.
- Vaccination significantly decreases likelihood of major new peaks. Magnitude of decrease depends on fraction of US population choosing to immunize, and the ability of new variants to overpower vaccine-related immunity. 
- Vaccine efficacy will decrease over time to an uncertain extent, potentially growing chance of a new peak if boosters aren't introduced
- If all locations in the US experience a local new infection rate peak at the same time (e.g., during common holiday times), then the magnitude of the US-scale peak will be much higher than if the "curve is flattened" by various geographic regions experiencing the same peak weeks or months apart (e.g., introduction of variants at random, with effects distributed in space and time) To assign probabilities to outcomes, first ask the probability of not seeing another spike before 1 May 2022. This requires the current peak not to get worse (my subjective prior: high chance), and no holiday peak > 200k/day (my subjective prior: very uncertain), and no unforeseen new variants changing the "predictable" evolution of the virus (my subjective prior: medium-to-high chance). Given current evolution of the Delta strain and expected consequences of public behaviors around holiday season, there will probably be some kind of new holiday peak, given prevalence of vaccine refusal and increased travel/congregation, but it very much doesn't have to be a big one. All in, I assess a slightly better chance than a coin flip that no new exceedance of >200k/day will be observed before May 2022 (~8 month window vs 1.5 year window previously observed, with the many caveats listed above). Next, assign probabilities to the other, earlier > 200k/day outcomes. 
Ultimately, I assign virtually all probability of a new > 200k/day outcome before May 1 to one of these scenarios: 
1) Delta persists and people travel/congregate over the holidays just like last winter, thereby causing a big new delta-driven peak that hits the >200k threshold. Subjective prior: a little better than 1/5 chance of combined Delta + families gathering leading to >200k new cases over the holiday season. However, based on last year's evolution of new cases, if this scenario is realized, the next 200k/day observation will much more likely occur "on the way up" during the peak, and this is much more likely to occur between Nov-Dec (vs Jan-Feb).

2)  A new, currently unknown, more infectious variant emerges, and spreads quickly across the US. My subjective prior: perhaps 1/5 chance of occurrence (uniform across next 8 months), so I equally distributed this probability between the middle three possible outcomes (each is of the same duration). 3) The current peak in new infections changes course and does get worse and hits > 200k/day, perhaps because of back-to-school or people spending more time indoors for some reason. If this happens it will express as ">200k/day before 1 November", and my subjective prior on this outcome is a little less than 1/10 chance based on differences in the evolution in this current peak of new cases vs the earlier one from last holiday season.
It is tempting to be optimistic as we see cases level off or drop but a look at last winter and spring does not give me enough confidence to go in strongly for "not before 1 May 2022".

Coronavirus is weird and hard to predict. While I think a downward trend is most likely, this dip in cases we're seeing could easily reverse course. Overall I'd say around a 3/4 chance we don't cross that threshold in the timeframe.

Hard adjustment on remembering that (as seen in the UK) a well vaccinated population can see a drop in cases as people with mild symptoms don't bother getting tested and therefore drag the tracked numbers down (irrespective of the actual infection rate).  This has been seen in the UK where the strategy has now moved to "learning to live with COVID" rather than "beating COVID" [1]. As detectability of cases drops, combined with the Biden initiatives / mandates for vaccine proliferation it seems fair to base significant certainty on the premise that the Trump era (i.e. unmitigated) high of 200k+ daily cases being experienced, detected and reported is, for the current strains, a thing of the past. I also note that some states (e.g. Nebraska) appear to have stopped reporting cases to the CDC (likely because of local government mandates) [2] which will have an impact on this question's resolution (and start a whole new political row in the margins). Leaving some possibility open for new variants emerging and surges in specific low vaccine states pushing numbers outside the predicted brackets over the holiday period. Rethinking. It would take a strain to infect ~15% or 16% of the US population to get to average daily totals >200k. Not even Delta is likely to infect that many. With Delta sweeping through now and largely wrapping up around December, and so many vaccinated, resulting in maybe >95% of the population with some immunity, it's hard to picture a wave that big happening so soon on the heels of Delta, or perhaps ever, depending on what variants emerge and how many people keep up with vaccinations.

Last year, the 7-day moving average of daily cases did not spike to >200k until Dec. 6, and it remained barely >200k from Dec. 6 to 24, when there was far less widespread immunity. Moreover, Delta is making its way through the population at the moment, and will likely cause a much smaller peak of cases this winter as population immunity reaches levels >90%. In addition, one or more new variants capable of taking Delta's place have not clearly emerged. In short, I don't see a strong case for >200k in bin 2, but it's possible. If one or more new variants emerge, perhaps even sublineages of Delta, then bins 2 or 3 could be possible, although a variant that substantially escapes existing immunity would be required imo. We're in uncharted territory here. Will cases start to settle down once nearly everyone in the US has some form of immunity? As for bin 1, I don't think we'll see >200k before Nov. 1 because I think the Delta wave will generally be winding downwards between now and Oct. 31 (with perhaps an additional, lower peak between now and then). I think bin 4 would require a variant with extreme immune escape. The fall/winter wave last year infected ~20% of the population (including all infections, not just confirmed infections). The Delta wave will infect ~12%. That is all this extremely contagious variant can do in the face of widespread population immunity. When Delta is done and around 95% or more of the population has some immunity to SARSCoV2, unless an extreme immune escape variant emerges, this winter may look like the low end of an endemic Covid season: perhaps 5% to 10% infected. Before the pandemic, flu viruses infected 5% to 15% of the population; a small number of people were susceptible each year as the virus mutated and children were born. Not everyone who was susceptible was infected each year. With Covid, I think it's reasonable to expect a similar or greater percentage of the population will become infected each year, due to waning immunity, genetic changes in the virus, and its high transmissibility. So, if ~12% brought us to >150k cases/day, and ~20% brought us to >250k cases/day, then ~15% will need to be infected to reach >200k. I don't think that's likely this winter, but new variants could emerge that could do it. It's stochastic, and there are a lot of cases providing a lot of opportunities.

most populous states, ie CA, TX, FL, NY the peak of infection of the unvaccinated in most large states will be reached soon enough... the vaccinations will continue...  A fall/winter surge is possible.. I don't expect it to rise to that level...

Starting pitch, operating on the premise that this Winter for several western nations (UK and US in this case) is projected by several notable scientific bodies [1] to follow a previously demonstrated seasonal infection trend and see case rates rise significantly as winter sets in. With several notable holidays that focus on social gathering coming up in the US over the period, and assuming that Biden's rules on workplace vaccinations will both be challenged by deep red Republican states and be only partially effective vs the more worrying transmission vector of unvaccinated children that are returning to school over the fall, it feels that this side of New Year is the most likely set of buckets.
